key_title: Key to the genera of Ericaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Ericaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Ericaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Stamens > 6
Stamens 4 or 5
Leaf-bases entirely sheathing stem; staminal filaments free from corolla and inserted at base of ovary
Leaves petiolate, sessile or stem-clasping, but bases never entirely sheathing stem; staminal filaments fused to corolla

Corolla not separating into lobes but splitting transversely near base, the upper hood-like part (operculum) shed, the lower cup-like part persisting; anthers free, glabrous; montane to alpine watercourses and bogs
Corolla lobes separating at anthesis, not forming a deciduous operculum; anthers cohering around the style, densely hairy; lowland (rarely montane) wet heathlands
[link through]
Style inserted in a deep depression between the carpels; fruit a capsule opening by 5 valves
Style not inserted in a deep depression between the carpels; fruit a drupe or sometimes the endocarp separating into pyrenes
Axillary inflorescences single-flowered, spicate or racemose, individual flowers subtended by a solitary persistent or caducous (sometimes leaf-like) bract and two bracteoles

Axillary inflorescences all or mostly single-flowered (rarely some 2- or 3-flowered) with subtending bracts and bracteoles collectively more than 3; bracts and bracteoles often difficult to distinguish from one another and grading in size to the sepals
Staminal filaments slender, terete to slightly flattened
Staminal filaments broad and distinctly flattened, ± fleshy
Inner surface of corolla tube glabrous except for 5 reflexed fringed ovate scales inserted above the middle; corolla lobes obtuse to subacute, imbricate in bud
Inner surface of corolla tube with hairs scattered or in tufts or a ring towards the base, lacking reflexed scales above the middle; corolla lobes acute-acuminate, valvate in bud

Inner surface of corolla tube with tufts or a ring of papilla-like glandular hairs towards the base; style less than 1 mm long; filaments becoming free from the corolla near the base of the tube; veins on undersurface of leaf several, parallel, unbranched and separated by deep grooves

Inner surface of corolla tube with hairs scattered, in tufts or in a ring towards the base, but hairs not glandular and papilla-like; style longer than 5 mm; filaments becoming free from corolla well above base of tube; midvein only visible on underside of leaf, or if several veins apparent then some branched and/or not separated by deep grooves
[link through]
Flowers solitary or 2–3, in a short spike; external surface of corolla glabrous; bracteoles less than 5 mm long, c. half the length of calyx
Flowers solitary; external surface of corolla minutely hairy or glabrous; bracteoles more than 6 mm long, c. two-thirds to three-quarters the length of calyx
Anthers much exserted from corolla tube on long erect filaments; filaments much longer than the anthers; style longer than corolla tube
Anthers enclosed within to shortly exserted from corolla tube on short filaments; filaments shorter than or equal in length to the anthers; style shorter than corolla tube
Hard endocarp of fruit not separating into pyrenes; pungent-leaved shrub 0.5–3 m high; near-coastal
Hard endocarp of fruit separating into pyrenes; blunt-leaved mat-forming shrub less than 15 cm high; higher alps
[link through]
[link through]
Bracteoles distant from base of calyx; inner surface of corolla tube glabrous in lower third to half, pilose above

Bracteoles inserted immediately below base of calyx; inner surface of corolla tube glabrous, or if hairs present, then confined to apex (i.e. in throat) and often in 5 tufts between the staminal filaments
[link through]

Throat of corolla tube partially or fully closed by 5 tufts of dense spreading hairs originating from near the junction of the corolla tube and lobes, the corolla lobes above wholly glabrous to minutely papillose or with an isolated subterminal comb-like tuft of long erect stiff hairs; flowers strictly in spikes borne on branchlets at least 1 year old; anthers much exserted from corolla tube on erect or strongly reflexed filaments; fruit 2–11-locular, endocarp ± separating into pyrenes

Throat of corolla tube not closed by hairs, or if partially closed then the corolla lobes above neither wholly glabrous to minutely papillose nor with an isolated subterminal comb-like tuft of long erect stiff hairs; flowers solitary or in spikes or racemes on current season?s or 1 year old (rarely older) branchlets; anthers enclosed or exserted from corolla tube; fruit 1–5-locular, endocarp not separating into pyrenes
Corolla lobes usually green, with a subterminal comb-like tuft of long erect stiff hairs; ovary and fruit 3–7-locular; widespread
Corolla lobes usually maroon, lacking a subterminal tuft of hairs; ovary and fruit 8–11-locular; decumbent shrub of montane to subalpine sites in the east
[link through]
Ovary 1-locular; corolla tube glabrous internally; corolla lobes glabrous, minutely papillose or rarely with a few very sparse inconspicuous hairs internally
Ovary 2–5-locular; corolla tube usually with hairs in the throat between the anthers; corolla lobes papillose or sparsely to densely bearded internally
Corolla lobes distinctly imbricate in bud, minutely papillose internally
Corolla lobes valvate in bud, sparsely to densely bearded internally (glabrous to minutely papillose in alpine L. montanus)
Flowers unisexual or at least functionally so; corolla lobes shorter or subequal to tube; anthers without sterile tip; alpine and subalpine areas

Flowers bisexual; corolla lobes usually longer or equal to tube, if ever much shorter than tube then flowers on distinctly decurved spike; anthers with or without a sterile tip; mostly from lowland and montane areas
Flowers all axillary, either solitary or in 2s or 3s on a short spike; anthers without a sterile tip
Flowers terminal and sometimes axillary, in spikes (sometimes condensed) mostly of >3 flowers; anthers with a sterile tip
Leaves narrow-linear, to 1 cm long; margins closely revolute; sepals and petals each 4; corolla persisent
Leaves obovate to ovate or lanceolate, 2 cm long or more; margins plane (but usually serrate); sepals and petals each 5; corolla deciduous
Fruit a globular berry, c. 2 cm diam., rough and orange-red at maturity; stems with gland-tipped hairs; tall shrub or small tree escaped from cultivation
Fruit a capsule, enclosed at maturity by the white or pinkish, enlarged and thickened calyx; stems with acicular bristles; weak montane shrub to c. 1.6 m high
[link through]
